turns.content: How long do pine trees typically take to grow to their full size?

Pine trees can take anywhere from 20 to 100 years to reach their full size, depending on the species of pine and the environmental conditions in which they are growing. Some pine species, such as the Eastern White Pine, can grow up to 3 feet per year, while others, such as the Bristlecone Pine, can take several hundred years to reach full maturity.
Goodness gracious! Several hundred years for a pine tree to mature? That's longer than the lifespan of some humans.

Yes, some species of pine trees can live for hundreds or even thousands of years, particularly those that grow in extreme climates or isolated environments. For example, the Great Basin Bristlecone Pine, which is found in the western United States, can live for more than 5,000 years. However, most pine trees that are grown for commercial purposes are harvested well before reaching their maximum lifespan, typically between 20-60 years depending on the intended use.
